issues.description: The problem statement's UML defines the Pneumatic interface with methods raisePressure(int) and openValve(). The solution repository's Pneumatic interface, however, declares raisePressure(int) and releasePressure() (method name 'releasePressure' instead of 'openValve'). At the same time, the solution's implementing classes (LaunchedDropdownTower and LaunchedRollerCoaster) implement raisePressure(int) and openValve(). This creates a structural contradiction: the interface in the solution does not declare openValve(), yet classes implement openValve() — causing a mismatch that will prevent the solution from compiling and confuses students about the intended method name. The template Pneumatic.java is empty (students are expected to declare the interface as in the UML), so the mismatch is between the problem/UML and the solution implementation.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the Pneumatic interface method names across artifacts. The simplest fix (and consistent with the UML/problem statement) is to change the solution repository's Pneumatic interface to declare openValve() (instead of releasePressure()). Concretely, replace 'void releasePressure();' with 'void openValve();' in solution_repository/src/de/tum/in/ase/Pneumatic.java so the interface declares raisePressure(int) and openValve(), matching the UML and the implementing classes. Alternatively, if the intended name is releasePressure, update the problem statement/UML and the implementing classes to use releasePressure() consistently. Ensure template, problem, and solution all use the same method name.

issues.description: The UML/problem statement declares the Pneumatic interface with two abstract methods: raisePressure(int) and openValve(). In the solution repository the Pneumatic interface defines raisePressure(int) but uses the name releasePressure() for the second method. At the same time the solution's concrete classes (LaunchedRollerCoaster and LaunchedDropdownTower) implement openValve(), not releasePressure(). This creates a naming mismatch between the problem description and the solution interface, and an internal inconsistency in the solution: students reading the problem will expect openValve(), the solution's interface uses a different name (releasePressure), and the concrete classes in the solution implement openValve (so they do not match the interface signature). This will confuse students about the expected method name and may cause compilation/verification mismatches.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the method name across artifacts. Preferred fix: rename releasePressure() in the solution's Pneumatic interface to openValve() so it matches the UML/problem statement, and ensure all implementing classes declare @Override public void openValve(). Alternatively, if releasePressure() is the intended name, update the problem statement/UML and task description to use releasePressure() instead of openValve().
